FacilityName: AGRIServices of Brunswick, LLC. - Brunswick West

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:    AGRIServices of Brunswick, LLC - West
Location:    Hwy. 24 West, P.O. Box 38, Brunswick, Mo.
Contact:     Jerry Young
Phone:     660-549-3351

1. The Facility Policy

AGRIServices of Brunswick, LLC, and the employees of the AGRIServices of Brunswick, LLC - West in Brunswick are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Brunswick Fire Department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of bulk dry and liquid fertilizer for direct application as a crop nutrient. Anhydrous ammonia for direct application of making liquid fertilizer. The facility also handles pesticides and grain. 

The facility has (1) 18,000-gallon storage tank, (1) 12,000-gallon storage tank, the 18,000-gallon storage tank is the largest tank onsite containing approximately 84,000 pounds. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a transport delivery truck holding approximately 50,000 pounds. 

3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1981", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

4. The Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia or propane in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental
